channel.title: Homebrew tape drive
channel.description: So, you all know I like teh retro stuff. I think I'm going mad because I want to make a tape drive that works with today's computers! To be more specific, I would like to be able to store stuff (prolly emulator roms) on tape! Weird I know! so here is my idea and how would I go about doing it?

item.title: Homebrew tape drive
item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx
item.description:
@peterbjornx wrote:

its easy, for example , if the 1 and the 0’s are always exactly the same voltage you could use a VCO

See this : http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commodore_Datasette

and loool:

With a PicAXE chip, you could get info with the serin command and then convert each letter to a tone, like 8e or whatnot then that goes out the audio port into the tape player then when you want to convert back to text and send to the computer then just download a different code, or just get a memory bank.
PicAXE - ROOOOOFLEEE use PIC’s without shit firmware, write ur own .

Read full topic

item.title: Homebrew tape drive
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

runescape3dude:

With a PicAXE chip, you could get info with the serin command and then convert each letter to a tone, like 8e or whatnot then that goes out the audio port into the tape player then when you want to convert back to text and send to the computer then just download a different code, or just get a memory bank.

Or I could use the Kansas City standard[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 17, 2009, 04:56:15 pm[/size][hr][quote=“peterbjornx, post:6, topic:319142”]either FSK’ing(frequency shift keying) or 8bit resolution audio (make a file, write wave headers then write data to save)![/quote]

frequency shift keying

from what I have read that sounds the best idea, now how to do it!

[me=bootnecklad]starts searching google[/me]

Read full topic

@runescape3dude wrote:

With a PicAXE chip, you could get info with the serin command and then convert each letter to a tone, like 8e or whatnot then that goes out the audio port into the tape player then when you want to convert back to text and send to the computer then just download a different code, or just get a memory bank.

item.title: Homebrew tape drive
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:2, topic:319142”]http://www.newegg.com/Product/ProductList.aspx?Submit=ENE&SubCategory=46&N=2010020046

tape is still a really viable backup solution[/quote]
C|P is right, it is used as a back up a lot we use it it at work for backing up things that are there for archivical purposes, the access time as yuo would expect is shocking so sotring documents that you will be using regularly is a bad idea imo
